newsitem.title: ITALY: Tears flow in Rome as O'Dell executed in Virginia.
newsitem.headline: Tears flow in Rome as O'Dell executed in Virginia.

text.p: While Joseph O'Dell was being put to death in Virginia, hundreds of Italians opposed to capital punishment held a countdown vigil in a Rome square hoping and praying to the last minute that he would be spared.
"Maybe the Pope will call the governor (of Virginia)," one woman in the crowd said minutes before O'Dell was executed. "That's the only thing that might save him at this point"
But she and others in the small crowed broke into tears when, via a live television hook-up from Virginia, they heard a spokesman for Governor George Allen announce dryly:
"The execution was completed at 9:16" p.m.
O'Dell, a convicted murderer and rapist, was killed by lethal injection and died after saying he was innocent.

"They killed a man who died proclaiming his innocence and above all a man who was very different than what he was 12 years ago when he was accused of killing the woman," said Alfredo Biondi, deputy speaker of the Senate and an ex justice minister.

The crowd gathered in Rome's Campo de Fiori square, around the statue of Giordano Bruno, the monk who was burned there for heresy in 1600 during the Counter-Reformation. They converged on the square after an earlier protest at the U.S. embassy

With many of them wearing T-shirts reading "Don't kill for me. I don't support the death penalty," the crowd watched on two mega-screens as live television hook-ups with Italian correspondents kept them informed of the events in Virginia.
Italy, which has no death penalty in civilian criminal cases, is among the most vocal supporters of a worldwide ban on capital punishment.
The O'Dell case became a cause celebre, with Pope John Paul, President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro and Prime Minister Romano Prodi making appeals for clemency to Governor Allen.
O'Dell was convicted for the 1985 rape and murder of Helen Schartner but had appealed for new DNA testing he said would prove his innocence.
But earlier on Wednesday, a federal appeals court in Richmond turned down the DNA request, saying the claim was "meritless."
"Let's not let O'Dell die twice," former family affairs minister Antonio Guidi said in the crowd. "Let's use this as an opportunity to spur us on to fight against capital punishment."
On a wall of one of the centuries-old buildings in the square, a bustling fruit market by day, hung a banner that read:
"The hangman does not go on vacation". It included a list of death row inmates who are due to be executed in the United States in coming weeks.
Actor Vittorio Gassman who was once married to American actress Shelly Winters, told a reporter:
"I don't think the death penalty is a deterrent against crime and I am shocked that a people as generous as the Americans do not rise up against capital punishment."
He added: "I have a daughter who is American and I think she would be happy to know that I am here."
Alfonso Pecoraro-Scanio, a parliamentarian of the Greens Party, urged Italians to boycott U.S. states were capital punishment is practised.
"I urge Italians not to go on vacation in American states that have the death penalty. Go to states where it is not practised," he said.
The O'Dell execution was carried out hours after the U.S. Supreme Court rejected an appeal 9-0.
Allen also denied O'Dell's last-minute plea for clemency, saying he saw "no legitimate reason" to justify overturning the judgement of a jury who heard the case.
O'Dell, 55, was married to his volunteer paralegal, Lori Urs, 41, in a midday wedding on Wednesday at the Greenville Correction Centre.
O'Dell was made an honorary citizen of the city of Palermo and has said he wanted to be buried there.
Luciano Neri, a parliamentarian of the Sicily-based La Rete party, said he visited O'Dell recently and that he asked that his grave in Palermo be made a monument against the death penalty.
